bboxes.raw_text:
Petitions containing 9011
signatures, over four times
the minimum required, we're sub
mitted by Frank Mangin. Republi-
can primary candidate for Cor
poradon Commission. Mangin,
who seeks the long term seat
now held by Democrat A. P.
Buzzard. filed his petitions with
Secretary of State Yves Bolin.


Veteran capitol observers
commented that this was one of
the largest signature filings by
a Republican seeking statewide
office this year. "The hard work
of the Republican Committeeman
and other volunteers in securing
signatures for all our candidates
is significant indication of real
grass-root strength for our
party, and certainly points to
further successes in September
and November" Mangin said.

The Arizona Brewing Co. of
Phoenix has announced modi-
fication of name of its Lancer's
Beer, to ]. F. Lanser's Beer.


Vice president ]. F. Lanser,
Jr., said the change on all labels,
cartons, bottles and caps, cans
and advertising will be COM
pleted by September /.


Lancer, Jr., explained that the
reason for the name change is
to perpetuate a memorial tri-
butte to the late ]. F. Lanser,
Sr. Mr.. Lanser died last Deem
Der after q years Of leadership
on both local and national levels
Of the brewing industry. He
served as president of the COM
pany from the time of purchase
in 1912 until he became board
chairman in 1862. He was a
president of Brewers Associa-
ton of America and a board
member of United States Brew
ers' Association.


In his early days with the COM
pany. the plant produced $4,000
barrels of beer known variously
as Hopi. Dutch Treat. Apache,
Sunbru and Wonderland. Several
years later it became Al Prem
ium Beer and, most recently as
Lancer's, a spelling calculated
to allow for correct pronuncia-
ton of the family name.


Today, the plant has 100000
barrel capacity and Lanser's
Beer is distributed in six states.


Among the firms other pro-
ducts are Lanser's Al Ale. Lam
ser's Book Beer, and prestige
priced draught beer known as
Oberheit.

George Gavin, local insurance
man has announced his candidacy
for the Democratic US. Senate
nomination. He was concerned
with our need now for clean,
businesslike government" and to
fight against "eMl influences that
have corrupted governments and
enslaved large areas of the
woodworking men and women Of
their freedom and their right to
govern themselves"


Gavin. 81, 5l1O E. Lincoln
Drive, owns and manages the
George Gavin Company. ad down
town insurance agency.


Long been active in civic and
community affairs in Arizona,
is former board member of
Catholic Social Service, direc-
tor of the National Council Of
Christians and Jews, and has
headed the Phoenix Knights Of
Columbus. He is a former presi-
dent of Phoenix Association Of
Insurance Agents and was chair
man of the City of Phoenix In
surance Committee.


He also served on the board
of the Phoenix Community Coun-
Gil, was a director of the Mari
copa County Safety Council, and
served as director of the St.
Joseph's Youth Camp.

Gerry, Larry and Robert
Oliver are attending Careers for
Youth camp.


Miss Alnetta Faye Hawkins and
her parents. MIR. and Mrs. Al
foster Hawkins, Of Flagstaff are
motoring to Texas and Louisi-
ana.


Mrs. Lou Anderson, Miss
Geneva Slade and Laura Ann
Cook, of Wichita Falls. Texas,
are visiting with relatives, MIR.
and Mrs. L. M. Murphy.


Mrs. Rena Muldrow Is visiting
relatives in Los Angeles.


Mr.. and Mrs. Levi Coleman
are visiting her father in Denver.


Happy learning to Mrs. Paul
Griffin who is attending sum-
mer school at the University
of Oklahoma.


Mrs. Lorraine Parker's
houseguest is her mother, Mrs.
Loretta Ruff, of Oklahoma City.
They we're guests at family
dinner at the home of Mr.. and
Mrs. Earl Bibbs.


Mrs. Ruby Forge and Gwen
dolyn Conner just returned from
a trip to Fresno, California.


Zion Rest Baptist B. T. u.
district congress is in session at
St. John Baptist Church. Rev.
Larry is the president of the
congress. Re. L. ]. Dunbar
is moderator.


Mr.. and Mrs. A. ]. Galbreath,
their son, Ronnie. Mrs. Dave
Gray and Mrs. Lena Mae Car
ruthers have returned from Los
Angeles.


Mrs. Charlesetta Coleman will
attend the Camp of the Woods.


Mrs. Johnnie Faye Coleman
is spending the summer with her
father in Los Angeles.


Mrs. Lille Belcher is letting
to Los Angeles to see the Dod-
gers weekend games.


l am happy to know Mrs. De-
metria Vann has returned from
tending her ailing father in
Arkansas.


Thought for the day = "Set thine
house in order.'' The Bible

William Blevins, singer, was
the South's first Negro radio an
nouncer.

dinner party honorng Mrs. D. Reed. Mrs. Ihieo
Church. of Shawnee Oklahoma and Mrs. Bertha Carey Marlin
Tex was Sunday the home Of Rev. and Mrs. woodrow '"
Reed, 4543 S. 10Th St.


The brothers and their sister MRS. Cessle
Sykes also present.
Others pictured Lewis Reed brother Rev. E. SYKES

young friends sample delicious watermelon.

aborers genial Santa provider school supplies
with big heart.

trying do his and help those less
